<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimeBaseGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_TimeBaseGetInfo(osal_id_t timebase_id, OS_timebase_prop_t *timebase_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *           record;
    int32                          return_code;
    osal_objtype_t                 objtype;
    OS_object_token_t              token;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *timebase;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timebase_prop);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    memset(timebase_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_timebase_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, timebase_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_timebase_table, token);
        timebase = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, token);

        strncpy(timebase_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(timebase_prop->name) - 1);
        timebase_prop->creator               = record->creator;
        timebase_prop->nominal_interval_time = timebase->nominal_interval_time;
        timebase_prop->freerun_time          = timebase->freerun_time;
        timebase_prop->accuracy              = timebase->accuracy_usec;

        return_code = OS_TimeBaseGetInfo_Impl(&token, timebase_prop);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>

<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
strncpy(timebase_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(timebase_prop->name) - 1);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call uses strncpy(timebase_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(timebase_prop->name) - 1). The destination is zeroed earlier (memset), so no out-of-bounds write and a NUL terminator is guaranteed. Assuming the invariant that record->name_entry is an array of size OS_MAX_API_NAME (i.e. at least sizeof(timebase_prop->name) bytes), the call will not read beyond the source buffer and thus does not violate Rule 21.17. A possible violation scenario would be if record->name_entry were actually a pointer to a smaller buffer or not allocated with at least sizeof(timebase_prop->name)-1 bytes: in that case strncpy could read beyond the source bounds and violate the rule.
